name: Kepler-169
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-169 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-169 is a star with 0.655 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.76 times its radius. It is located 1341.61 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-169 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-169 b

Kepler-169 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.25 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-169.

The mass of Kepler-169 b is 1.30 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-169 b is 1.13 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-169 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-169 c

Kepler-169 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.20 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-169.

The mass of Kepler-169 c is 1.52 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-169 c is 1.21 that of Earth. At 1.52 Earth masses, Kepler-169 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-169 d

Kepler-169 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-169.

The mass of Kepler-169 d is 1.66 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-169 d is 1.25 that of Earth. At 1.66 Earth masses, Kepler-169 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-169 e

Kepler-169 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.77 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-169.

The mass of Kepler-169 e is 6.36 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-169 e is 2.2 that of Earth. At 6.36 Earth masses, Kepler-169 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-169 f

Kepler-169 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.36 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 87.09 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-169.

The mass of Kepler-169 f is 9.34 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-169 f is 2.58 that of Earth. At 9.34 Earth masses, Kepler-169 f is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.359 astronomical units, and a mass of 9.34 Earth masses, Kepler-169 f could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-169, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
